response.answer_text: Q: “When will the modern Catholic Church collapse and why?” Good question. I think about it often. However, I sense impatience; that is not wise. We should be thinking not of the events outside of our control, — so-called eschatological events, — but of our own, personal demise. When will I collapse? And more importantly, in what condition will my soul be when I collapse? Will I have a good death? Will a priest be nearby? These thoughts are good to have; the Church recommends we think often of the The Last Things and apply them to ourselves. It is also wise to pray to Our Lady, because she is, really, our church, and she won’t collapse. Holy Mary, Mother of God, pray for us, sinners, now and in the hour of our death. But I digress. Your question is formed with precision. “When will the modern Catholic Church collapse?” That is an important distinction, for the Church in her essence cannot collapse any more than Mary can collapse, or Christ can cancel His death and resurrection. You understand, no doubt, that the Catholic Church exists outside of time and space: it is a supernatural force, that connects us across time to the foot of His Cross and the Empty Tomb; it gives us fellowship of Christ on His throne of majesty; it united us with the Holy Apostles and the first martyrs for the faith, and all Christ’s saints through the ages. It is not collapsible. At the same time the modern Church, — that is, the Church post Vatican II, or the 15th century German Church that was a breeding ground for the Protestant Reformation, — is an institution of fallible men, so she may fail. Not in the eternal sense but in temporal sense. She failed to hold Northern Europe in unity of faith. Earlier, she failed to hold Byzantium and Russia in the unity of faith, she failed to sustain the military struggle of the Crusades to liberate the Promised Land. Schisms and surrender are failures of the Church. “Collapse” is too strong a word, because the Holy Spirit leads the Church out of every disaster our bishops drive her into. The Great Eastern Schism of 1054 becomes a gift to us today, because as we in the West mangle our liturgy, the Greeks preserved for us the splendid Church of antiquity and early Middle Ages. If Protestantism had never had a chance to develop its theological fantasies, there will forever be a temptation to fall into declarative, effortless faith of “total depravity” of man and of “irresistible grace”, — these are easy, entry-level theologies that come back to tempt us now and again. Having tried them we know where we ought not to go. The concern for the Modern Church is very real. That we survived the Eastern Schism, and the false popes, and the Protestant Reformation does not guarantee that we shall survive modernity without some rather fundamental change. It is entirely possible that the Church will shrink to a very small faithful kernel. The triumph over the Gates of Hell is certain; how many will persevere to the end is not known. Christ said: yet the Son of man, when he cometh, shall he find, think you, faith on earth? (Luke 18:8) These words cannot be dismissed. True, He is asking rather than prophesying, He just spoke of God avenging His Elect in the previous verse. He is not going to abandon us. But His words are spoken for us to hear. Many are losing their faith because of our faithless clergy, poor catechisis, organized Atheism. One American bishop once commented that he is about to end his days in his bed, but his successor is likely to end his days in prison, and his successor’s successor is likely to end up executed. These are not unfounded fears, and at the root of this condition is the failure of the Modern Church. Pope St. Pius X outlined the failures of the Modern Church; they are many and his encyclical is long. Here is my outline: Alex Pismenny's answer to Who is the most conservative pope? Later, Pope Benedict XVI summarized the problems of the Modern Church in three words: “dictatorship of relativism”. This is where we get theology of personalized faith that is plaguing Catholics today. We now got ourselves a pope who, when he is not busy covering up for faithless clergy, chats with the press about how he is “not one to judge” and how for all he knows, an Atheist can get to heaven just fine. For him, I pray often. The keys that he is holding better be dropped and picked up by someone. Maybe, his aging predecessor?  But these are day-dreams. The Modern Church is not going to leave the scene voluntarily; she is not going to collapse, of course. She is going to phase out. In a generation or two. As every conservative Catholic knows, the Catholic youth is conservative. Best priests are young priests. They have seen the shenanigans of their parents, and they want their Church back: the Church of the Upper Room, the Church of the Catacombs, the Church of the Romans, the Church of the Middle Ages, of the cathedrals and monasteries, of the saints and of the scientists, the sculptors and the iconographers. We are going to be fine — our grandchildren, that is. The rest should be prepared for rough times ahead. Hold tight.

I used to read a lot of the writings of Fr. Andrew Greeley, a priest and a professionally trained sociologist. He made the study of the Church a large part of his life’s work. He found that people raised Catholic might drift away from the Church and stop attending, but they just would not go to other churches. Once raised Catholic, they might not go to services, but they stayed Catholic. And of course, they came back often for milestones. This is a tendency which virtually guarantees that the RCC is not going bust any time soon. They are one of the largest denominations of the assortment of Christian denominations, and probably one of the most literate. Churches whose demise I fully expect are all of the non-denominational churches. The group itself will not go away, of course, but virtually all of the individual churches will experience a period of growth, a period of stability, a period of decline and finally it will be shuttered. This is because while the pain line denominations have a large body of traditions, and experience in dealing with almost any kind of difficulty, the non-denom is out there all alone. Most of them do not have much knowledge, and when some special kind of problem hits, they founder. They also tend to be personality cults, so that when the magical parson who founded the church retires, often that’s the end of the church. I’ve visited a number of RCC parishes. Many of them are quite beautiful and seem to have a very loving atmosphere. I visited one because it is the modern incarnation of a parish my ancestors attended many, many years before. I almost wish I hadn’t come. It was a very sturdy church, but it looked like a business proposition, not a religious setting. Very antiseptic feel. However, when I was visiting was not when a service was scheduled, and I saw a good number of the faithful in the sanctuary, so it’s obviously doing the important things right… I wonder what people are thinking when they ask if the RCC is going to fail any time soon. The answer is about as certain as one can be at this stage, that such is not going to happen any time soon. There are a number of different denominations, and each of them is doing reasonably well, all things considered. People who do not go to any organized church have experienced a growth phase, and the number of non-believers (agnostics and atheists) has increased so that they are pushing ten per cent. In the recent past, commitment to the church has dropped. Are these the beginning of a trend? Only time will tell. It’s nothing remarkable at this time, certainly, and we have seen rises and drops in these numbers many times in the past.

They’ve proven very durable, despite generating heretical spin-offs and schisms for most of their 2000 years, so I believe the Catholic Church will be around for a very long time. As to why a collapse might come, when it finally comes: look at examples in history of other churches that disappeared. It will probably be for secular and financial reasons, not by converting people’s hearts. Example: Constantine I made Christianity legal in the Roman Empire in 313. Theodosius I made it the official Roman state religion in 391. For the 78 years in between, there were still several powerful churches in the Empire, including the old pagan state religion and a unitarian (Arian) version of Christianity. In fact, there were both pagan and Arian emperors after Constantine. Theodosius allowed attacks on pagan temples and eventually ordered them closed. He confiscated temple money. He disbanded Rome’s Vestal Virgins. Fortune-telling by examining animal entrails was banned, on pain of death.Unitarian Christians had to turn over their churches to the Orthodox/Catholic Church.Probably most importantly, Theodosius passed a law that unitarian Christians could not make legal wills and could not pass their wealth to their children. It would be taken by the state. No one wanted that.So, one way to end a church is to ruin it financially. At first people will only pretend to give up their old religions, but after a couple of generations the old religion will be gone. There are definitely exceptions, including Christianity and Judaism in Europe, but it has happened often. Arian Christianity continued in non-Roman European kingdoms until the 8th century, but eventually they were all conquered and converted by Catholic Orthodox countries. Of course this is also how all the South and Central American religions died out. The lands were conquered by Christian Spain and Portugal, and the old religions were suppressed by force.

I take “the modern Catholic Church” as referring the particular form and structure under which the eternal Church is manifested at this particular point in terrestrial history. The question then becomes, at what point, and from what cause, will the everday workings of the Church become so different from what they are now that it will be impossible to say that her current form still exists? In other words, if the primitive Church represents one stage in ecclesial history, and the Church today represents another, when and why will we see the next stage after this? Well, I’m no seer, Heaven knows, but my guess would be that it will have something to do with the reconciliation of Russia. Our Lady tells us this is going to happen eventually, and I can’t imagine that it will be unaccompanied by certain theological developments - notably a clear enunciation of the limits of papal authority, with a corresponding increase in the perceived status of individual bishops (not their real status, which of course doesn’t change) - that can’t help but have dramatic and far-reaching consequences for the day-to-day life of believers everywhere. Plus, the mere fact of having this huge, influential, culturally rich nation and its unique religious spirit suddenly joined to the Body proper - well, that’s just going to change things willy-nilly, isn’t it? As to when this is going to happen - well, your guess is as good as mine. As near as I can make out, the Pope could set it in motion whenever he chooses; it’s just a matter of writing a prayer consecrating Russia to the Immaculate Heart and commanding it to be prayed somewhere in every Mass, at least by the celebrant. But first he has to want to do so, and we seem to be on the ninth pope in a row who doesn’t want to. (Which is bizarre to me, since I always thought that bringing souls into the church was the primary objective of a pope, and leaving 150 million of them outside because you can’t be bothered to spare five minutes for their reconciliation seems like the sort of thing that would be hard to explain at the Judgment Seat. But maybe they’ve just been intimidated by the thought of so momentous a grace being dependent on their action.)

I think the Catholic Church may reduce its power and its number of followers along the next centuries, but I doubt it will collapse to the point that it will be unsustainable and eventually disappear… Or rather, I think that, when that day comes, that may be because the entire boat of Christianity as a religion is sinking fast. Despite what I perceive, at least in my country (Brazil), as a dangerous and generalized apathy and sameness, a loss of the urge to spread the gospel and compete for the souls and minds of people, a decrease in the number of young priests and nuns that only the blindest and most stubborn Catholic will refuse to notice, a sort of “shrugging” attitude in the face of very strong and increasingly radical competition by evangelical churches and non-religion advocates… Despite it all, I think the Catholic Church still has a huge advantage: it’s strongly built, it has solid foundations that are the result of cumulative effort of dedicated people for two millennia. More than its material wealth, which has actually been slowly overridden by that of big evangelical churches whose faithful unfailingly pay their tithes (and a few of them even charge as much as 30% of their followers’ income!), what’s the strongest feature of the Catholic Church is that it has a slowish but ultimately efficient and resilient organization, it has true institutions, above all it has a richly developed theology and an actual intelligentsia to maintain and develop its doctrine and tradition. It’s also, unlike so many other churches, a church with a very clearly defined identity and a millennia-old tradition and intellectual output all of its own to offer to the Christian followers as unique aspects that won’t be easily found elsewhere. Your average Catholic won’t witch from the Catholic Church to another “catholic-like church” that looks very similar, but less old-fashioned or more congenial. So, in my opinion, the collapse of the Catholic Church could happen if, unlike in previous times of change and crisis, the Catholic authorities completely refuse to adapt to the new circumstances and to make the necessary amendments to their institutional and organizational practices, even if that does not mean, obviously, changing the dogmas and the core, truly religious principles of the Church. I think that’s unlikely: though the process of change in Catholicism has always been slow and tentative, very carefully done, it ultimately happened, and the Church went on in a somewhat renewed form. That’ll probably happen again sooner or later, no matter how the ultra-traditionalists wish to believe, without basis on the real history of the Church, that everything, including the slightest rules and costumes, has always remained exactly the same since the primitive Christianity, and the traditions and doctrines never developed gradually, organically, without clear ruptures along the centuries. The other possibility for the complete collapse of the Catholic Church is, of course, if Christianity as a whole is completely destroyed by the spread of another religion or by the generalized shift of people to irreligious belief systems. But, since humankind is always so varied in behavior and thought, I confess I find it very doubtful that some day we’ll have such absolute unanimity on spiritual and more broadly metaphysical matters, so even if Christianity and, with it, the Catholic Church decrease tremendously, I’d expect some small groups of Christians to remain faithful to their beliefs.
